comments.text: I am sorry for clarity, does each one of the Wago components join 5 wires together?
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text: Yes, each WAGO module connects all five wires together.  Think of it as a spring-loaded wire nut, like what is used in house wiring.  The advantage of these modules is the wide range of wiring it can accept (12AWG - 28AWG), and high load rating (20A).  This module is for 5-wire connections; they also offer 3-wire and 2-wire connections, but I only needed connections for this.  I think I may have created another strip that holds four 5-wire modules, but may not have posted that.
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text:
thank you! can you recommend a link to the wage elements with 2 and 3 wires that have the same rating?
thanks!
comments.author: Tackleberry

comments.text: It's easier than you think; here are Wago's part numbers for each of them:
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text:
I saw those, are these any better by chance?
thanks for your help!
http://a.co/6KMU4gh
comments.author: Tackleberry

comments.text: I've also used those, and they are a nice improvement over the 222 series.  They need 11mm stripped wire (vs. 10mm), and they don't take quite as wide a range of wires (24-12AWG vs. 28-12AWG).  But, the levers are larger and have a lower spring force to open.  Also, they are a smaller fit, so they work better in small spaces.
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text: Thank you again. Do you think they will work with the thin wires of small computer fans?
comments.author: Tackleberry

comments.text: Absolutely!  Those wires tend to run 22-24AWG if I remember correctly.  Just make sure you don't have any pulling forces on the wires (strain relief would be best, if possible).
comments.author: psdesign

comments.text: Thanks. Already ordered
comments.author: Tackleberry

title: Click Stop for Mk 6+ extruder tensioner ( 3mm filament)

description.text:
During lengthy builds, the screw adjusting the pressure on the delrin plunger loosens, and the stepper fails to supply filament to the hot end.
These parts provide a positive click stop for the adjustment bolt, which prevents it loosening.

Print out the bolt end cap and press it onto the bolt, it has a hexagonal insert that should be aligned to the bolt.
The back plate is bolted to the extruder housing using the existing bolts and nuts. The nuts fit into the recessed hexagonal holes on the back plate.

author: AwesomeA

description.text: fake cctv. you can connect cable.

These files are for turning a BB8 art deco wall light into a Halloween basket.

My daughter is going as Rey this Halloween and I thought a BB8 themed basket would complete her outfit (since she already has a 3d printed staff).

Take the BB8 wall light, remove the electronics, and use these printed pieces in place of the black plastic wall mount. It's easy to salvage most of the lights from the wall light if you want to still use those. Warning - the basket itself requires a large print bed... it just barely fit inside my Robo3D R1.

You will need some counterweights to keep BB8 from falling forward. I used 2 M10 25mm bolts and 4 nuts. There's holes designed into the basket to hold them.

print_settings.Notes:: Note: Cura seems to have a problem slicing this design. It tends to fuse the hinges in some places. Slic3r and Simplfy3D slice it correctly.

description.text:
This is my attempt at designing a "fidget widget". It is mostly for to me practice 3d cad tools.

While not a remix, inspiration was drawn on the many great fidget widgets on thingiverse.

I print this without support. It shouldn't break when you try to free the joints. Please read the printing instructions for successful results.

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

33% (use higher for a heavier feel)

Notes:

I print this flat with 4 joints facing up.

I have updated the model a bit so 33% infill, at 0.2mm resolution, prints without any danger of broken joints when freeing the cubes the first time. I use a zig zag infill pattern which looks nice to semi-transparent or glow filaments.

Print temp is 195c, I heat the bed to 60C for the FIRST layer only. That provides for good adhesion but the bed cools off after so it doesn't cause a layer curling issue later. Having a heated bed for all layers can cause failed prints due to curling from uneven cooling while printing the filleted edges on the bottom layers.

Note: Cura seems to have a problem slicing this design. It tends to fuse the hinges in some places. Slic3r and Simplfy3D slice it correctly.

title: SLC Free Wideband Oxygen Sensor Controller Case

description.text:
This is a 3D printed case for the open source and low cost SLC Free Wideband O2 sensor controller from 14point7 ( http://www.14point7.com/products/slc-free ). This controller will connect to a wideband oxygen sensor (Bosch LSU 4.9 or LSU 4.2) and tell you the Lambda value (Air to Fuel ratio) of your exhaust. It has a linear output, as well as a narrowband output, which emulates a narrowband O2 sensor.

I didn't like the metal standoffs included, nor having just a bare PCB exposed while using it, so I made this case. I strayed a bit from the standard build by using different connectors, so I included a middle and bottom piece for lots of variations.

If you soldered the wires directly as recommended in the instructions (or used the white Molex connectors that weren't recommended), use the _wires files. I used C-Grid III (locking shrouded) connectors, which surround the pin and make contact on multiple sides, rather than the single sided connection from the white Molex connectors... and housings that lock into the connector. If using them, use the _cgridiii files. The specific parts I used are: 90136-2205 and 90136-2206 (connectors), 90156-0145 and 90156-0146 (housings), and 90119-0109 (crimp pins). Since they're shrouded, I had to install them on opposite sides of the board for them to fit. I also had to snap off the outer tabs on the rear of the connectors for extra clearance around the mounting holes (see the pics for details).

I also installed connectors for the programming header and additional I/O. If you want the programming header accessible, use the _prog files, and if you want access to the I/O pins, use the _io files.

Note that there are several variants of SLC Free... A is open source, B and C are closed source. Variant A only has a bar graph, and only works with LSU 4.9 sensor, B and C show the values in text, and are for the LSU 4.9 and LSU 4.2 sensors respectively. I included case parts for all three types... _a has labels to interpret the bar graph, _bc just has lambda and temperature labeled. I'm currently running variant B (seen in the pictures), though have a spare chip and programmer, which I plan to use to load variant A (and possibly customize the firmware if I ever need it).

The Sketchup model for all these pieces is included as well.

Assembly

Once you have the desired top, middle, and bottom pieces printed, you need to place the SLC main board into the middle piece, and then flip it over and press the LCD into the socket. It won't go all the way into the socket, as the middle is also used as a standoff to keep the LCD board from touching the top of the capacitors on the main board.

Then put the printed top and bottom on the assembly and attach with #4-40 screws. The top screws should be approximately 5/8" long... for the bottom, the tall bottom piece (_cgridiii) should use 5/8", the short bottom piece (_wires) should use 1/2".

What's it used for?

I used this to debug a problem on my truck, which was causing me to fail my emissions test. I had a high NOx value, and very low HC and CO values. These values told me that I was likely running very lean (too much air, not enough fuel), so rather than making a change and paying for another test (and probably failing), I swapped the OEM narrowband O2 sensor with a LSU 4.9 wideband sensor, connected it to the SLC Free, and connected the narrowband output to the connector that OEM sensor was plugged into (since the truck ECU needs an O2 sensor signal).

This let me make changes (cleaning fuel injectors, fix vacuum leaks, etc), test drive it, and see my AFR in real-time while driving. After making some changes, I got it where the burn was nearly stoichiometric (Lambda=1, approximately 14.7:1 AFR) during normal driving, so I put in a new narrowband O2 sensor (the old one was destroyed while removing it), took it to the emissions test station, and PASSED! :-)

I also plan to use it to tune my motorcycle. By putting the O2 sensor in a tailpipe clamp in the muffler, I can tweak the fuel tables for optimal performance. This only works for vehicles without a catalytic converter, like many motorcycles (otherwise, you need to put the O2 sensor before the cat to get an accurate reading).

title: Kitchen Towel Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This wall mounted Kitchen Towel holder features a hinged arm for compactness when not in use and can be unfolded to hold a 10" length kitchen roll.

A friend of mine had the same Premier Kitchen Towel holder in his kitchen and since his broke and finding a replacement would be near impossible since this thing came as part of a limited time free gift item with the kitchen towels. Kudos to my friend for the pictures.

I decided to design and 3D print a similar functioning holder using Blender. The holder works well when the body is printed in PLA, while the arm was printed in PETG (though PLA would be sufficient but the added flexibility from PETG makes it easy for loading/removing).

Please ask permission when commercializing more than 10 sets.

Instruction:
1) Assembled model is for reference, do not print!
2) Print 2 set Arms and 1 set Body (or for smaller printers, 1 set Body_HalfA and 1 set Body_HalfB, then weld or glue the two halves)
3) Use 1.7 mm garden wire or PETG/PLA filament for the hinges.
4) Use double sided tape for mounting on the wall.

layer_height = 0.2

Recently I tried to find one of the old-style hex-wrench stands we have laying around the shop and they simply don't exist anymore. In fact, I was unable to find anything that would hold sizes over 3/8"; I wanted a holder for every common size up to 1".

So, after a good bit of math and design work, here it is. It holds the 22 most common hex-wrench sizes, commonly available on McMaster-Carr, from .026" to 1".

I've allowed plenty of extra space in each size, but not so much that any other wrench can fit in that spot.

I've included two versions, one that uses simple hole-diameters and another that uses the actual hex shape.

Currently these are just plates. Ideally these would be remixed into either a wall-mounted version or one with legs. Right now it's just a plate with properly made holes, no legs or mounting accommodations made. Maybe I'll do a future version with legs / mounting plates in place. But if you really want to use this for now, I suggest laser-cutting it from 1/32" steel, dog-bone shaped, and then bending the ends down to create a tall stand.

Or, if you print this in plastic, catch it from the ends with wood or something to create a stand.

The hole-only version is fully filleted, but I left the other undone to match the old-version we have in the shop from 30 years ago. Basically, the round one is for making in thick materials like plastic or wood, and the hex-shape one should be used for thin steel or aluminum, thus you don't need a fillet on it.

Lastly, this is under public-domain dedication, feel free to take for whatever use you desire and remix as you please.

Enjoy!

author: all-kas

description.text:
I finally got feed up with the self lubricating bearing supplied with the unit (too much slop, chatter restricting speed). I ordered some plain LM8UU and made a bearing block to suit.

Please note I used a number of metal 15mm stand-off for axis adjuster and mating between bearing block and belt bracket. (Bracket to follow).

I also had to adjust the DELTA_SMOOTH_ROAD_OFFSET & DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD values.

Once I fitted and tested the unit ran ALOT quieter and I was able to double my print speeds and maintain a high accuracy.

title: Thanos Figurine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Why waste plastic on a torture test, this is pretty much a torture test and you get something out of it at the end that's a bit prettier.

Print difficulty 7 out of 10 - only for the reason that people seem to have issues with supports. I used Meshmixer to generate supports (4.0mm, 45' threshold) when printing mine and I printed it once, it was fine first go.

Thanos on the Throne.

Essentially I could not afford the $800 official Thanos model so I crafted my own.

I have included both versions with and without supports. No special printing requirements, I printed this on a printer that doesn't even have a PLA cooling fan and it seemed to handle the supports ok.

title: Deck boxes for Magic collectible card game

description.text:
This is a collection of deck boxes for the Magic card game. It fits 100 sleeved cards nicely. The logos for the five mana types are embossed into the fronts.
It was a request for a Highlander format deck of 100 cards. (this is a modification to my previous V:tES deck box: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16480)

Pick a model for the Bottom, print in desired color. Then print the generic Top in the same color.
I set the infill to 100% solid for structural integrity of the walls.
It might need a tiny bit of sanding to get the pieces to fit together smoothly.

comments.text:
WOW! I'm not buying cards any more. I have a ton already anyway. I just finished building my printer, and was all excited to print out some magic boxes - and WOTC made a take down order??? I buy 6 boxes of cards per year, plus a couple of precons, prereleases and the occasional draft. Is that not enough money? and how do they block a box? what? it has a trade marked mana symbol??? this was user created content. If this is the box I'm thinking of, the cool part was how the box worked, not that it had a mana symbol.
I got plans to design some magic related stuff myself. If they try some take-down #@!% with me, I'll sue their asses. I hope they do.
PLEASE! If this pisses you off contact WOTC here:
US/Canada: (800) 324-6496
Other Countries: (425) 204-8069
I just estimated that I spend about $800 -$1000 per year on MTG, and I WILL NOT buy their stuff till they fix this.
Please call! trust me- corporations WILL LISTEN to complaints like this. Hell, just consider the cost of paying people on their phone line to listen to us complain. That combined with reflect poorly on their reputation, decreased sales, etc.

Adjustable platform for calibrating the gyro and accelerometer of radio controlled vertical launch vehicles such as quadcopters,

Print these parts. No support required. The pylon and lift are hollowed out with open bottoms.
One base. One pylon. One platform. Two lifts. Two cylinders.

The triangle pattern in the platform is called an Isogrid.

Press the pylon and cylinders into the base, secure with glue if desired (or if the fit is loose). Glue the gears to the top of the lifts, they're used to turn the lifts to adjust height.
Snap the lifts into the corner sockets.
Screw the lifts halfway into the cylinders then snap the other socket onto the pylon.

You'll need a bubble level to adjust the platform.

I printed one, had to tweak the diameter of the pylon base and shorten it. Also added some reinforcement to the sockets on the platform.

The lifts need the ends of the pegs at the bottom sanded just a tiny amount, and some careful force is needed the first time turning them into the cylinders. It helps to glue the gears onto them first.

Print at least 30% infill on the lifts and pylons and platform, with 2 perimeters for strength on the balls and sockets.

Test printed lift and cylinder. Pegs at bottom seemed to be too long, despite having plenty of clearance when modeling, so I shortened them some.

Second test print and the lift still won't thread into the cylinder. Could be because I'm doing quick prints at 0.3mm layer height. Ah, just got it to go in with some force. Probably have to carefully sand the ends of the pegs, and use thinner layers, higher % infill too.

The gear does fit the top of the lift and will have to be glued on.

author: mankidal

description.text:
This is a CoreXY 3D Printer and CNC.

Upgrade your 3D Printer to this frame! Re-use your motors, electronics, hotend, heatbed, etc...

Watch how the HyperCube came to be:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n2jM6v3E7sU&list=PLIaArjwViQRVAERWRrYfe9rtiwvvRGCzw

I wanted to reduce the weight of the moving mass as much as possible. As the entire X-gantry is moving in the Y direction, the rails for the X axis should be light too. I chose to use 10mm anodised aluminium tubing, which is half the weight of 8mm steel rods.
And have since moved to Carbon Fibre tubes, which is one eighth the weight of 8mm steel rods.

Marlin 1.1.4 Configuration.h files attached.

BOM

Frame:
T-Slot 2020 (Slot/Type 6) Aluminium Extrusion Profiles for X200 x Y200 x Z155 print bed area
(Note: If you intend to make a larger print area, then increase the length of the 2020 extrusions AND rods for each axis by the difference)
Buy from Banggood - Silver, Black or Buy from Amazon

  • 4 x 340mm (X)
  • 4 x 303mm (Y)
  • 4 x 350mm (Z)
  • 2 x 285mm (Bed)
  • 1 x 135mm (Bed)

Fixings

  • 60 x M5 x 8mm button head screws (Amazon)
  • 60 x M5 x 10mm button head screws (Amazon)
  • 2 x 100pcs T-Slot M5 hammer nuts
  • 3 x 10pcs Aluminium Corner Brackets

CoreXY + Z + Bowden Drive System:

  • 2 x 8mmx300mm Hardened Steel smooth rod (choose 300mm length) for Y axis
  • 2 x 8mmx350mm Hardened Steel smooth rod (choose 350mm length) for Z axis
  • 2 x 10mmx360mm Anodised Alu tube OR Carbon Fibre Banggood or Amazon for X axis
  • 1 x 10pcs Self Lubricating Bushing or for Carbon Fibre tubes Igus JSM-1012-10
  • 4 x LM8UU linear bearing for Z axis
  • 2 x LM8LUU linear bearing for Y axis
  • 1 x T8 300mm Lead Screw
  • 1 x 5x8mm Aluminium Flexible Shaft Coupler
  • 2 x 10pcs F623ZZ Flange Bearing
  • 1 x 5M GT2 Belt
  • 1 x 2Pcs 2GT-20 Teeth Timing Pulley
  • 1 x Teflon PTFE Tube
  • 1 x MK7 Extruder Gear
  • 1 x Push Fit Connector M5

Fixings

  • 45 x M3 x 10mm pan head screws (Amazon)
  • 45 x M3 x 20mm pan head screws (Amazon)
  • 2 x M3 x 6mm pan head screws (Amazon)
  • 2 x M3 x 35mm pan head screws (Amazon)
  • 35 x M3 Nyloc nuts (Amazon)
  • 35 x M3 Hex nuts (Amazon)

Motors, Electronics and Accessories:

  • 4 x NEMA17 Stepper Motor
  • 1 x 3pcs Endstop Switch
  • 1 x RAMPS 1.4 + MEGA2560 R3 + LCD&SD + A4988 With Heat Sink Kit
  • 1 x 12V DC 50mm Blow Radial Cooling Fan
  • 1 x Heatbed Aluminium MK3 12V 24V
  • 1 x 12V 30A 360W Switching Power Supply
  • 1 x Thermistor 100K With 1M Cable for Heat Bed
  • 1 x DC power wire (choose 14AWG)
  • 1 x 10M Tinned Copper 22AWG 2 Pin Red Black
  • 1 x 5pcs Bed levelling screw/spring/knob
  • 1 x Genuine E3Dv6 or Clone (1.75mm long) with optional Block & Sock v6 Upgrade
  • 1 x Inductive Proximity Sensor - PNP

Print settings:

  • 3 Perimeters
  • 3 top/bottom layers
  • 0.25mm layer height (or better)
  • 50% infill

Print 1 of everything except below:

  • 2 x Z_Carriage
  • 4 x Z_Carriage_Clamp
  • 4 x Z_Shaft_Clamp_v1.1
  • 2 x XY_Clamp_v1.1
  • 2 x XY_Joiner_v1.1
  • 2 x XY_Idler
  • 3 x Y_Shaft_Clamp
  • 4 x Bed_Support_v1.1
  • 2 x Dual_Bushing_Holder

Some useful extras:
HyperCube 3D Printer Accessory Pack
HyperCube CNC Toolheads
Compact Bowden Extruder, 1.75mm Filament for MK7 Drive Gear
Various Z nut mounts for Integrated Leadscrew Motors

X-Axis 10mm Anodised Aluminium alternatives
If you can't find 10mm x 360mm anodised aluminium tubes for X axis, and besides using Carbon Fibre tubes, there are 2 alternatives:
HyperCube XY_Joiner for 8mm rods on X-Gantry
X Carriage Mod for 3/8" Rod and Bearing for HyperCube 3D Printer

Notes:

  • Bed_Support_v1.1 for revised bed configuration (build log video #11)
  • Z Endstop v1.1 for revised bed configuration.
  • Z_Motor v1.1 and Z_Shaft_Clamp v1.1 for bottom mounted motor
  • Fan_Duct v1.1 with extra clearance for E3D silicone socks
  • Fan_Duct v1.2 for easier bridge printing
  • X-Carriage v1.1 provides extra support to belt mount.
  • XY Joiner/Clamp v1.1 supports longer bearing LM8LUU and dual LM8UU bearings.
  • Configuration.h files updated to Marlin 1.1-RC8
  • Removed old file versions. Can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2013921
  • E3D (Inductive) Sensor Mount v1.1 for improved sensor mount stability
  • New X_Carriage & E3D_Mount & E3D_Sensor_Mount for removable tool heads!

Enjoy this design? Consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/Tech2C

comments.text: I see. You blow air through the fan duct to the hot end. Is that necessary?
comments.author: the_greek

comments.text:
"I see. You blow air through the fan duct to the hot end. Is that necessary?"
absolutely necessary, in short the the E3D H/ends require active cooling continuously while printing " else you get whats known as heat creep". the second "parts fans", will come on intermittently. As and when your slicer calls for it , so combining the two aint a good idea as you be blowing air on the first layer which in turn cools the base far quicker and you'll be prone to curling and lifting before the prints finished.
comments.author: the_greek

comments.text: would the recomended 220v power supply be okay to use in Australia with 240v?
comments.author: PontiDude

comments.text: Yes. 220/230/240V is usually all the same technology with different naming, and either of those will work in Australia. Same with 110/115/120V being the tech generally used in the USA. It's mostly only those two different groups that you have to deal with. (Apart from Japan with its own 100V but you can't buy that kind of tech anywhere really, anyway)

comments.text:
I finished my build a month or two ago and I wanted to warn everyone about the RAMPS board. They can be of very varying quality. My first one had resistors soldered wrong as well as a few solder bridges that I had to fix. It eventually stopped connecting to my PC. I bought a second one, and after many successful PLA prints I decided to try PETG. I cranked the bed temp to 70 degrees and after an hour of printing the RAMPS lit on fire.
Be careful everyone! Don't leave your printer unattended.
comments.author: MrChefur

comments.text: Yes, if you buy cheap this happens. The mosfet in the chinese ramps boards are absolutely not rated for this high power draw. You can buy better mosfets but the best choice is to buy a good quality board in the first place. You will not regret it when your house did not burn down. I am e.g. using this ramps: https://www.tindie.com/products/staticboards/ramps-14-sb-premium/
comments.author: MrChefur

comments.text:
Yeah, luckily I learned the easy way. I've always had a rule to never leave the house while the printer is going, and it saved my butt here.
I've decided to upgrade to a Duet WiFi and just skip the RAMPS platform altogether,
comments.author: PurchenZuPoden

comments.text: I created this solution for protecting against a 3D printer catching fire.

comments.text:
• With a donor prusa i3 this upgrade ran me ~140 dollars including getting all the 3d printed parts off of 3d hubs. You might want to build your own spreadsheet based off of your BOM to make sure you don't buy extra, or have the right things. One thing to check is screw sizes, My printer came with m3x18 rather than 20, and that made it completely unbuildable, Its the same scenaro for screws that are too long, so be sure you've got that right. If you use your smooth rods from your old printer, what I did was use the Old Y axis for the new z-axis and old z axis for the new y axis to have a bigger z axis, and support for a bigger build platform. I of course bought aluminum extrusions to accommodate it.
    I have a rough BOM i used, with things I already owned at 0 dollars, and some parts excluded.
    https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1j3N9XlgUaAO4dJPid-zl5Ue5vKTI2duEhL0H3Y4b9gc/edit?usp=sharing
  • idk
  • idk
  • Most of you pars should be good, but you'll probably need to get lots too.
  • You don't need new firmware for the build volume, but you will need to reflash to change the motion to corexy as far as I know
  • Yes

comments.text:
Hallo Leute
Mein erster Drucker ist aus der Idee des Prusa I3 entstanden, als freier Nachbau. Mein zweiter Drucker wurde nach dem RepRap X400 gebaut. Dieser hat auch einen kompletten Rahmen aus 4 Kant Alu- Rohren und funktioniert eigentlich tadellos.
Nun hab ich meinen Prusa i3- Name JOII1- schon des öfteren umgebaut und verbessert. Er läuft jetzt wirklich sehr gut und zuverlässig. Er hat nur einen Fehler. Die Höhe eines Werkstückes kann nur 130 mm betragen. Das ist mir zu wenig.
So hab ich mich entschlossen meinen JOII1 in einen HYPER CUBE umzubauen und diesen auf ca 400 mm Höhe zu bauen.
Im Augenblick druckt mein JOII1 die Eckstücke für den ALU Rahmen des neuen Druckers. Seine Teile werden dann in den HC- namens FREDY eingesetzt.
Ich werde im Laufe der zeit einige Bilder einstellen.
comments.author: Georgio

comments.text: Achtung, bei 400mm Bauhöhe zieht das Gestell vom Druckbett ziemlich an den Linearachsen...  ich würde bei so einer Höhe direkt auf seitlich montierte Linearführungen (am besten Richtung MGN12 + MGN12H Gleitwagen, aber auch 10mm Achsen würden sicher funktionieren) mit einer(!) Traverse setzen, auf welcher dann das Druckbett montiert wird, z.b. mit zwei weiteren Extrusionen. Das ganze entweder mit zwei Motoren an den jeweils gegenüberliegenden Seiten der Traverse bewegt oder noch besser, ein Motor und über Zahnriemen.
comments.author: Georgio

comments.text:
Ja da haben Sie auf jeden Fall recht, doch ich werde das Druckbett wieder so aufhängen wie ich es bei JOII2 , wie bei X400- gemacht habe,
mit 3 Schneckenachsen , eine hinten in der Mitte und je eine links und rechts Vorne. Somit ist der Zugriff auch frei , aber die Plattform, das Druckbett stabil.

Bonjour André, j'ai également imprimé certains de mes designs en ABS, mais j'ai constaté que je devais utiliser un PSU de 24 V pour passer un MOSFET pour chauffer le lit. J'ai dû chauffer mon lit à 110 ° pour obtenir quoi que ce soit pour imprimer correctement. Je ne pouvais pas faire réchauffer le lit jusqu'à plus de 95 ° en utilisant le PSV 12V.
Si vous pouvez joindre l'imprimante, même partiellement, elle vous aidera également à imprimer l'ABS.

comments.text: I assume you mean the hot end moves in both A and B and not that both motors turn as that is normal when moving in only. When wanting to move in only the direction both motors should turn otherwise the hot end will move. If both motors are turning but the direction is incorrect then the most likely answer is that one of the motors is wired backwards. This is easy to test by changing Marlin or by flipping the motor connection and then trying the move again. comments.text: I assume you mean the hotend moves in both X and Y and not that both motors turn as that is normal when moving in only X or only Y. When wanting to move in only the X direction both motors should turn otherwise the hotend will move in a 45 degree line. If both motors are turning but the direction is incorrect then the most likely answer is that one of the motors is wired backwards. This is easy to test by changing Marlin or by flipping the motor connection (with the power off) and then trying the move again.

comments.text: Hey guys, I am just about finished with the build. Can I print the hot end plastics with PLA or does that need to be in ABS? I just dont want to get it all running and then have it go flimsy cause I used the wrong plastic.
comments.author: brothainchrist06

comments.text:
I did print it in PLA, but I'm re-printing it in ABS now that the printer is assembled. I have several PLA parts that are breaking or cracking .
The Z shaft clamps, the Y endstop bracket, the X carriage face holding the belts.
Basically, every pieces where a force is applied you should print it in ABS or PETG so it has enough flex to support the constraints.
You can use PLA, but some pieces will break after a few hours of usage.
comments.author: brothainchrist06

comments.text: Excellent, thank you. I have not printed in PETG yet so I will have to get a spool of that and give it a try. But for now, I will continue to use PLA. I'll have to do some research on PETG and give it a shot. Thank you!

comments.text:
I want to make one of these with a 300x200 mm bed. Is it possible to make it like this with a single Z axis stepper, or would I have to do two?
Also, can someone clarify which axis is X and which is Y on this printer?
Thanks for the awesome design by the way, I'm looking forward to building one.
comments.author: Jackflef

comments.text: on your 300x200 bed,300 would be Y axis,200 the X.No matter if you look from front or back,X moves side to side,Y moves forward/backward.Personally,I think you would need 2 Z steppers with a 300 long bed,but I must stress,I have no personal experience with that size bed.
comments.author: Jackflef

comments.text: I have been running with a 270 mm x 220 mm bed with one Z axis Stepper. I upgraded to better bed supports and the 10 mm bearing rods. 8 mm bearing rods will not work very well. There is too much flex. If you orient your bed so the 200 mm direction is the one hanging out and you upgrade to 10 mm bearing rods, I think it will work fine.
comments.author: Jackflef

comments.text: Thanks! I think I'll do that. Would you mind sharing what changes you had to make to upgrade to 10 mm rods?
comments.author: henryarnold

comments.text:
I remixed the Z axis bed supports to have longer arms and retain LM10UU bearings:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1950819
There are also other bed support designs that use 10 mm bearing rods.
comments.author: Jackflef

comments.text: Thank you for sharing! I'll definitely use that.

comments.text: I am curious if anyone has a detailed list of where each type of screw will go. It's listed that M5x8 and M5x8 are needed with 60 of each being used. Let-alone beginning the parts being put together. Maybe I am just struggling due to all the changes that occur in the videos.

comments.text: It's M5x8 and M5x10. M5x8 are used for the corner brackets (28 brackets with 2 screws each) while M5x10 are used for all printed parts that are mounted to the frame (I think 46 screws in total plus some screws for the accessories like extruder mount, spool mount, etc.).

Over the past weeks/months I ordered every part, redesigned some parts and printed them. Now it's bulding time! The x carriage is already put together and all printed parts have their nuts and bolts. While building the frame I encountered a little problem: using the corner brackets from banggood it's not so easy to put the frame in angle and without tension. I think you have to loosen the screws on the corner brackets, align the extrusions and then tighten the screws again. Unfortunately the t-nuts didn't stay in position very well and I think about either using other t-nuts or other brackets. Any tips?

comments.text: I think it be worth increasing Z axis for sure, theirs a few fine examples in the made section.
comments.author: dan3008

comments.text: Thats the same thing the guy at my local maker space said lol. His basic advice was dont make the bed bigger than needed, but any extra height is always worth it if you have the room.
comments.author: jinx

comments.text: sound advice :P... its true on scale of things printing objects larger than 200x200 we talking days print!! not hours. but the hypercube current dimension  rock solid just a little short on Z. and it doesn't cost that much more from a scratch build with  500mm beams and 380 Z and 2 extra beam for Xy supports. still with the current  dimension it possible to slip a heat chamber inside the  frame. with a 380 Z  commercial delta  struggle for that :P.
comments.author: dan3008

comments.text:
Much more than print times (although, I can see that being an issue) bigger print beds take more power to heat, tend not to heat as evenly, can be harder to level and are more prone to warping...
ok, im almost convinced. I want a bigger print volume than the A8 this will be replacing. So I might go for a 250mm-300mm^2 bed, and just use as much Z space as I have :)
thanks for the input, really helpful
comments.author: jinx

comments.text: go for an AC powered bed using an SSR triggered from the board. I have a 350mm round bed that heats in 3-4 minutes. down side is the heater is 340mm so the edges don't get quite as hot, enclosure helps and I don't usually print much larger than 300-320 anyway.
comments.author: dan3008

comments.text: would it be cheaper to buy a reprap prusa i3 and convert it to a hypercube or just by all the parts separately?
comments.author: thatsherriff

comments.text: at first it does seem a smart plan, but those cheap kits tend to have lower quality fresh hold. you may end up paying more to replace the crappy parts!! you could take the tronics , power supply,motors and smooth rods, but you left with a pile of unusable stuff like frame, belts, screws. now on the flip side if you dont a have a printer to print the hypercube parts to start with it could save you cash, rather than buying the parts from a 3rd party. it make a good start learning the software like slicers and firmware installation and so on. if you undecided if 3d printing for you than a cheapie printer want be a bad start either. BUT if the budget allows you have both use the cheap one as part maker. I find its help having two if you some how break a part on the cube thats prevents you printing you got the other to fall back on plus it lets you tinker with one while printing with the other. in this day and age there's better controllers out there, 32 bit board with web interface have a peek at smoothie boards, mks Sbase for 8 bit boards look at RUMBA everything you need on a single board. the RAMPS have served us well and for a basic machine it will do just fine but let it die with grace! " dont go building the latest with obsolete parts the hyper cube will last for years and years dont go buying parts you replace later.
comments.author: thatsherriff

comments.text: thank you so much, very helpful. I already have an anet a8 so i wont be worrying tooo much if the hypercube breaks

I finally got my bed to home at the top,but now,when i click "up" in Pronteface,my bed goes down,and vice versa.
Anyone know which line in Marlin I need to edit to correct this?thnx.
comments.author: clogs

comments.text: Isn't that what is supposed to do? It's the bed that moves up and down, not the extruder. It may confuses you because Prusa type printers, do the opposite, but if you think a little, the part "grows" descending the bed, so it's normal that when you send up, the bed goes down, because what you are doing is raising the distance between the bed and the extruder. Is it clear this way?
comments.author: clogs

comments.text:
I'm not quite sure what to expect,but you may be right.
Pronterface may not be recognizing the fact that it,s controlling a corexy printer.
I'll try print a test cube and see what happens.

comments.text:
@jmlcatarino is correct. When you click 'up' in Pronterface for Z, think of the nozzle height from the bed.

comments.text: Hi, I intend to do the same. Did you use any special settings in the controller firmware to prevent the heated bed from drawing a lot of current at once. My controller supports 24V and I have a 24V power supply but I have an old 12V MK2A heat bed which I want to reuse. Can you share a picture of your setup.
comments.author: TechGirl_Mods

comments.text:
My controller also supports the use of 24V, but, I am actually using 2 power supplies one 12V and one 24V.
The controller is wired up to use 12V for everything and I am also using a MK2A heatbed wired for 12V.
The heatbed output of the controller is only used to switch the MOSFET via an opto-isolator, which in turn connects the 24V to the heatbed. At no time is the 24V connected directly to the controller it is only connected to the heatbed via the MOSFET switch.
The effect of all this is to at least double the power of the heatbed.
For the diagram see my make http://www.thingiverse.com/make:319553

comments.text:
On testing my hcube,I found the printer making horrible grinding noises as the x travelled along.The y motor was not moving,just vibrating back and forth a little.The cause was found to be one pair of coils on the y motor connected the wrong way around!Don't trust the colours of wiring on any chinese made stepper or cable!Use an led to test.
Moving smoothly now,just have to reverse the Z endstop,as the bed wants to home to the bottom of the printer.
FWIW, when using the chinese made Dupont style connectors,the pins are very loose in the socket.This can lead to the pins being pushed out as the socket is inserted on the ramps board.(or whatever you've got).Found this out the hard way,took me a while to notice the offending pin sticking up out of the socket:(..In short,make sure the pins are all the way in,and stay there.
Also,my lcd screen is a dud,it has most of 1 line of text missing.Tried a different set of cables,no change.New one on order.

comments.text: I don't know if anybody else has posted this yet, but for those in the US that are trying to make a Hypercube and are ordering from McMaster Carr, the 2020 aluminum extrusions that they sell won't work with the other parts that are listed in the BOM.  The T-slots on their aluminum extrusions are actually only 5mm wide, so the hammer nuts will fit lengthwise, but then won't turn to lock in place.  I ended up ordering (or rather re-ordering...) all of my rails from Misumi USA.  If this doesn't work, then I'm screwed.  I'll reply to this comment in a week to say whether or not the Misumi stuff works.

comments.text: I have MKS Gens on both my HyperCube and my Prusa i3. They are Mega+Ramps compatible but in one board. I like the JST connectors which matched my original HicTop controller. There really isn't much difference electrically to the Ramps. MKS skipped the reset-able fuse which I hear can cause problems. I would say the quality is better depending on where you buy your Ramps. MKS also claims better power conversion on board than Ramps. I don't have direct experience because I haven't run with a Ramps setup.
comments.author: mlbuxbaum

comments.text: I'd use the MKS GEN-L. Unless you buy an expensive brand-name RAMPS you risk getting cheap Chinese crap which melts the second you turn it on, I've had two cheap RAMPS boards do this. MKS GEN-L runs Marlin or Repetier (whichever you prefer) and you can change the stepper drivers. The GEN-L is half the price of the old MKS GEN.

So basically where the middle piece needs to be in between the arms have the leadscrew straight? If so, have the bracket screws loose on the arms so you can slide the middle piece. Then play with it back and forth and let it settle naturally. Tighten the screws careful since the torque action of the screws might push the piece forward.
After that's done, bring the Z axis down and see if the leadscrew lines up with the rods and do this again on top.

comments.text: Super Simple building tip for all.  I am currently building my Hypercube.  I have sleeved most of my cables.  I did not want to just have cables, even with sleeves laying all over.  I contemplated how to get the sleeved cables to stay in the 2020 tracks, then BAM, it hit me, I would just use a small piece of clear packing tape.  It is great, it is clear, and you can hardly see it at all, you can put pieces every 6 inches or so and they keep the cables in the tracks.  If you ever need to redo wiring, simply remove the tape, and put new tape, DIRT Cheap and quick and easy to install.  Soon I should have my running then I will post my entire make.  Cheers!

S3D has all those options;
Randomize Z height change - In Layer tab > Start Points (Right hand side)
Extrusion after retraction - In Extruder tab > Ooze control > Extra restart distance ( positive number extrudes extra above retraction distance, negative number extrudes less.

You either cross belts in the back (like this one, but this actually looks wrong because the crossing is not right http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:730199, this looks right but not printable http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22005 or have 2 levels like is done in hypercube and smartcore 1.2). I really like the openjscad with customizeable sizes and the fact it's gpl3 that allows commercial use. Regarding sound not sure I've built repraps both with m8's and wood, both are equally loud..., for abs printing you want a closed build volume anyway so adding a door and a top will reduce the sound I think. Also with hypercube it would be nice to add extra panels to print abs properly.

comments.text:
The youmagine is actually the old version. The latest version is on OnShape. You can find the links for it in the comment section of Smartrapcore's page.
I read a lot about smartrapcore, unfortunately after I built it, on reprap forums and reddit. tbh I don't remember what exactly is wrong with the way they implemented corexy. But what I do remember was something about belts having different angles which results in different steps per mm in different points on Y axis. I'm not sure if that made any sense... :D If you look at the image on smartrapcore's page, you see the belts going around the pulley do not go straight into the bearings at the end.
It's all on reprap forums, just the matter of finding it.
Yeah, adding panels in the front and top should reduced the noise. I plan on adding acrylic panels for Hypercube.
comments.author: wALLe

comments.text: Hmm hard to decide now, either go with smartrapcore and modify parts should they have issues or modify the hypercube parts to work with a wooden frame... (indeed the moving pulleys from x-carriage and L+R engine pulleys and back idlers need to be exactly in 1 line or you'll have tension issues, at first glance the 1.2 version looks ok on youmagine, the side that does not go straight is ok because that one is fixed length it's the moving one on the side of the carriage that has to be straight all the way). For now I'll go with smartcore because if I can make that work properly I can sell kits without worrying about licensing ;) Ofcourse it's gpl so any improvements I'll post also ... And thanks for the tip about OnShape, didn't even know that existed yet ;). Also the leadscrew on z ax is better. Using belts for z has the issue if power goes down your plate will drop and also should the plate become heavy the z engine is constantly working just to keep it in place...

comments.text: Is there a reason why the x/y-motors are in the front and not in the back?
comments.author: cyberdyne

comments.text: I don't suppose there's anything to stop you putting the motors at the back,but it may get a bit crowded.The idler pulleys would need to go to the front then.Don't know if that would affect the belt directions.
comments.author: cyberdyne

comments.text: With the the motor and the rods for the buildplatform there is already unused space in the back so why not put the motors for the x/y movement back there as well. This way there should not be a problem with fans or level-sensors or other stuff near the extruder hitting the motors. Yes the idler pulleys need to be in the front but they are much smaller then the motors. For the new configuration you just have to switch x and y motor from left to right (or Switch the connections on the controller). I just wanted to ask if there is an obvious reason (that I just can't see) not to build it like this.
comments.author: clogs

comments.text: The obvious reason is that it reduces the printable area. You lose the width of the steppers from the build area, at the back and you don't get it back at the front because of the print head. Or to put it another way, the steppers at the front take up no print space because the print head already limits the motion in that direction, but if you put them at the back they are taking up usable print area. You could flip the print head, which would give you back some print area, but not all of it (since the print head cannot move past the Z rails).
comments.author: cyberdyne

comments.text: H-bot configuration has skew/rotate issues (it tries to rotate the x-ax when moving). The whole reason corexy is invented is to mitigate this (it moves this rotate force onto the carriage alone instead of the whole ax). You can also have corexy that crosses belts in the back and then have it all in one plane, its actually what the alu version and the old smartcore and the original corexy that do this http://corexy.com/implementation.html. What you see is that the belts are crossed and thereby at an angle in the back. However the alternate corexy is using 2 planes like on hypercube and has advantage that all belts run straight + mitigates the h-bot issue http://reprap.org/wiki/CoreXY
comments.author: cyberdyne

comments.text: I've seen several people ask about where to buy extrusion so I thought I would post a link to where I got mine.  I found extrusions in lengths close to what I needed, and then requested that they cut them to final length.  They did the cutting for free, and all of the pieces arrived accurately cut to length.  They advertise the slot width at 6.2mm, and that appears to be about right.  M5 screws and t-nuts fit with no problem.  Just do a search within the store for 2020, and then find the lengths closes to what you need.  They also sell corner brackets, t-nuts, linear rod, and bearings so I got almost everything in one place which helped with shipping cost.

comments.text:
Hello, anybody knows how to get rid of nasty vibrations ?
The carriage has a very nasty vibration at only 30 mm/s, seems to be caused by the left stepper motor, but how to fix it ?
I tightened everything securely, reassembled the carriage but still same vibration .
Did anybody had this kind of vibration and was able to fix it ?
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: i had that problem just a couple days ago. It was because one of the wires in the dupont connector that actually plugs into the ramps board was not seated in the housing well. I redid all the connections and put on a new connector and fixed the problem. Just a suggestion.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: The vibration you describe is not normal. Try exercising each motor separately. If it is the Y motor. Try using the X driver to run the Y motor to narrow down if it is the driver or the motor. Have you checked your driver currents. Sorry if that was already suggested. The other suggestion about checking jumpers is a good idea. You may just have bad motor or driver.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
• Make sure the jumpers on your board are connected correctly. Seems like you are not microstepping.
  • Unplug and plug your motors back in. Might be a bad connection.
  • Try switching the motor drivers to find out if one is faulty
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
I have a Printrboard board from my former One Up printer, this one doesn't have jumpers, and I don't know about the microstepping if it can be done in the firmware or it is hardwired to same value . But the One Up was very very quiet with the same board and motors, so this is really strange . All the current pots are as originally and never touched them, steppers are not heating up.
What I can see and sense is that the carriage is vibrating when it is moved by the left motor, the one that is driving the belt on the top and which has the toothed pulley set up further away from the motor . It is like there is some resonance that is transmitter from the belt of the left motor to the carriage which the vibrates and makes this noise . Of course the noise grows as the speed grows ... I am just looking for idea how to diagnose this kind of vibrations, I ran a print with just the right motor connected to the board and of course no vibration . If you have any ideas about finding the cause of the vibration, you are welcome to put them here .
comments.author: easymonkeyboy

comments.text: I am coming from a Two-up and my board worked after the build without issues. I am fairly sure the issue doesn't lie in the belt but the board or motor. Try what Webguy said to narrow down where the problem lies. The Printrboard doesn't have drivers though so just switch the x and y motor connectors to see if that changes anything.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: based on your description, my guess would be that one of the steppers is not turning with the same ratio as the other. Both turn by themselves without issue, but together they cause a vibration. You could test this by hooking one motor up and sending it +100mm and see if it actually did that distance, then check the other motor moves the same distance. This is just a helpful guess.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
Actually it's the other way around, in a corexy when only one stepper is turning, the carriage will move at 45 degree angle on both axis .
I have my infill set up to a 45 degree, and it is alternating after each layer, so each layer one stepper is continuously moving back and forth and the other is just incrementing one step .
When the left one is doing the infill, the vibrations appear .
When the right one is doing the infill, no vibrations just normal running noise .
comments.author: makeshift_

comments.text: Wouldn't it be easier to exchange the stepper drivers? Also if there is any friction in the system, you should be able to feel that when turning the single steppers by hand.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: Already done that, replaced left stepper with Z stepper, same problem remains.
comments.author: mbruehl

comments.text:
Latest update, I have exchange the steppers between them, and now the vibration is caused by the right stepper (before it was caused by the left stepper), so the vibration seems to be connected to the same driver, but the pots for current are same for all the drivers, what can I do ?
I will try to set up the carriage with 8 mm and ball bearings, maybe it will move easier and the load on the drivers will not be so much ?
Is this a good idea or what should I do ?
My board is the black Printrboard from the One Up, so I can't exchange drivers as they are soldered.
Also how easy should the carriage slide on the aluminium rods, my carriage is sliding very difficult with the brass bushings, more easy with IGUS plastic ones, and very very easy with ball bearings . Can this affect vibrations ?
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: Maybe I'm misunderstanding but if the vibration followed the stepper motor as you moved it from the left to the right mounting locations, wouldn't that indicate a bad stepper not a bad driver? If you had bad driver, the left location would have continued to vibrate as you put a different stepper there.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: So I just switched the connectors on the board, I didn't move the steppers on the printer. So before the left stepper was connected to the driver for X axis and was doing the vibrations, not the right stepper is connected to the same driver and is doing the vibrations .
comments.author: henryarnold

comments.text: In that case, I agree that you have a bad driver or it is setup wrong. You said there are no jumpers so the only thing you can check is the current setting.
comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text: Anybody knows what is the right VREF that needs to be set on the Printrboard ? somewhere I found 1.45 V, somewhere I found 0.5 V, my potentiometers were all at 12 o-clock and approximately 1.0 V, the steppers are all running very cold so I thought to up the current maybe I get rid of vibrations ?
comments.author: henryarnold

comments.author: bbogdanmircea

comments.text:
Hi there folks,

comments.text: I built a working HyperCube for $450. There are people who have built the HyperCube for $280. Buying the cheapest power supply, the cheapest extruder, and other parts may give you an unreliable printer. As an example there are E3D extruder clones for $14 but they probably don't work very well. I used quality components and hardware and did not use any parts from my Prusa i3 which I used to print the HyperCube parts. Below are most of my costs for building my HyperCube.

comments.text: henryarnold for some reason I haven't seen your build before. It is extremely well done, congrats. I also went with the black extrusions, but grey printed parts. I'm totally using that in my next build :D
comments.author: henryarnold

comments.text: Thanks. Although the mounting plate on the bottom has it's advantages, I sometimes think I should have mounted the electronics on the back possibly in a box. I  added a Plexiglas shield to keep bits of plastic from falling into the electronics (not shown in photos). The bottom plate has the advantage of compactness and proximity of display, electronics and motors for wiring but the disadvantage of being open to stuff falling into the electronics. Mounting on the rear has the advantage of better protection and possibly a cleaner look but the disadvantage of more wiring up high on the printer. Overall I do like having my printer closed from the bottom by the plate and after adding a plastic cover it looks neat. Either way could be made functional and good looking.

i don't use autoleveling for z axis and it is really hard to control.

comments.author: bakmibaso

comments.text: by autoleveling - do you mean "homing"? Because autoleveling is for inductive sensors, and homing is for endstop switches. Autoleveling is where the sensor reads positions on the bed and the software accounts for the bed not being completely perpendicular to the gantry. Homing is when the bed moves itself up to the endstop switch.
comments.author: bakmibaso

comments.text: Probably because you may not necessarily need to print the Bowden stuff if you already have that setup on your existing printer.  Saves getting confusing for folks just doing an upgrade :)
comments.author: Fubar_1

comments.text: Yet most of the bowden parts are on the BOM....I can't understand why the plastic parts are not included as well so you'd have everything you need for a working printer.
comments.author: FunkyDiver

comments.text: If you need the Bowden parts, then buy them.  If not, then don't.  The guide kinda assumes you alreay have a printer as it's an Upgrade route (as given by the first line in the description), if you're struggling to decide what you need it might be more prudent to ask.  If you know which parts you do and don't need... what's the issue?

comments.text: I'm running into an issue where a pronterface command to move the X carriage left or right yields some forward or backward motion in the Y axis.  This doesn't always happen, but often enough.  Any ideas what might cause that?  I've tried Google and haven't come up with much, perhaps I don't know the right terms with which to search. comments.author: AllCity-Maker

comments.text: CoreXY system require each motor to hold its position and not have one win.  If both motor current is not set the same one motor could cause movement in the other thus resulting in undesired movement in the actual carriage.

As soon as I start tightening the XY Clamp on any side, X axis gets skewed. Everything moves very smoothly on both axis even when skewed.
If I loosen the XY Clamp I can fix the X axis again.

comments.text: My friend and I installed our belts on both of our HyperCube printers by one of us holding the X carriage against the rear of the printer while the other tightened the belts. We both were able to get our carriages square and the belts tight. I suppose you could clamp the carriage in place and then install the belts.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: I haven't installed belts yet. Was your X axis skewed before installing belts?
comments.author: henryarnold

comments.text: once the belts installed  push on each of them you see the yx joiner move slightly, now if one was inclined they could make a widget which could  tweak those  position, but really after 20 min of adjust those belts it be fine.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: My x carriage was 3mm off before tensioning my belts.  I found that sliding the carriage all the way to the back(butted up against the end with the z rods and leadscrew) and tensioning then sliding it back and forth a few times and then checking to make sure the x/y joiners both contact the edges at the same time was the best method.  It took a few tries before I had it perfect.  Good luck.
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text: Yeah, I played around with it a little bit and got the gap to 2-3 mm then made it even with the belts.
comments.author: wabamad

comments.text: Awesome!  I'm cleaning up my wiring tonight then installing my e3d and heatbed.  Hopefully printing before tuesday.  Glad you got your skew sorted.

comments.text: No, it was square. Installing the belts tends to pull on the carriage if the tension is not even. I misunderstood what your problem was. You axis should be square before and after installing the belts.

comments.text: Hi there guys.! My printer is finished and ready to print, but I'm facing with an issue that I didn't predicted. When the carriage is moving, there's a tiny play on the X carriage that makes the nozzle to get lifted or lowered depending on where it is. I mean, when it's moving, there are the cables and tube for the filament hanging there and that little amount of drag is sufficient to make it unstable. I think I overestimated the aluminium tube because it may not have the ridgidiness to handle the forces involved. I might have to change the rods and bearings to 8mm. Have any of you faced with this? Any suggestions?
comments.author: jmlcatarino

comments.text: you got a vid of it in motion , are the  bearing sleeves a snug fit on the tube?.  and maybe add more length to the cabling so it aint forcing the hotend mount up! hard to say without seeing , thou this was a problem early on with tech2c, but it also happens if folks are passing the cabling where the print  fan should go. if this is just a cabling issue and bowden cube hanging switching to 8 mm bar may not solve it either there can be play in those lmu88 bearing.

comments.text:
Hi. I have been experimenting with printed bushing. Most materials have a strong stick-slip effect and therefore less useable for bushings. But for obvious reasons carbon filled PLA works very well. My current Prusa is successfully running on carbon filled PLA bushings.
You might also consider to get the Iglidur filament from igus, specially developed for bearings, to print your bushings.
Success

comments.text:
I am going to build this printer. What a great design and very easy to understand tutorials! Thank you very very much!
How difficult would it be to change mechanical endstop switches to optical? Here is the one as an example:
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text:
Why would you want to go for the optical end stops?
The position of the endstops is not critical, they are only sampled once during homing and neither is the durability.
Although electrically it will not be a problem to use the optical endstops , mechanically it is much more difficult than a switch. If you want to use optical sensors you might consider to go for a reflection sensor for example TCRT5000.
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text:
There should be no need for a second leadscrew if you stick to the regular bed with 20x20cm. I build my hypercube with 50cm long extrisions and so far use a regular 20cm bed (untiil the 40x40 cm bed is ready) on 35cm long extrusions, and this is a rigid structure. This may also be due to the fact, that I use 10mm steel rods for Z.
I will add a second leadscrew as soon as I got the bigger bed. I will turn the Z-Axis-carriages to go along the X-Axis then, as the rigidness oft the Y-axis will be ensured by the 2 leadscrews and tilting left/right will be the major problem then, not the tilting front/back.

Hi. I've checked myself since I am thinking about sourcing the parts.
T-slots are usually higher-density, ticker aluminium (weight per meter) so more rigid frame as a result. The better the brand, the higher the density, thus more rigid frame.

comments.text: I am having issues with vibrations on my prints. If I move the printer in Repetier they are smooth as butter in X and Y. But when printing the whole printer is vibrating and if I put my hand on the X-gantry there is strong vibraions. Of course this shows on the print where all straight lines are "knurled" a tiny bit. Not smooth. When doing infill there are less vibrations and the print looks good. I am thinking it might be an issue with the motor drivers?
comments.author: easymonkeyboy

comments.text: Sounds like your stepper drivers need adjusting. These are the tiny little circuit boards on top of your main board, and control the step action of your motors. Theres a small screw on top of them which can be turned to 'tune' the motors. There's some info on it here: http://reprap.org/wiki/Pololu_stepper_driver_board#Tuning_motor_current
comments.author: easymonkeyboy

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. I have been testing everything I can possibly think of with the stepper drivers. What makes me think that they are not the problem is the fact that the head moves silently when giving it directions in repetier. However when homing and printing it is vibrating. So I know that the machine can run smoothly it just seems like it chooses not to when printing haha.
I was debating if it had to do with the print speed and resonance but I could not get it any better when trying different speeds. I know that the vibrations definitely come from the motors. They are all set for 1/16 step. Do I need to change something in the firmware to make them realize that? Could they be set at 1/8 when printing? Maybe something in repetier?

comments.author: mlbuxbaum

comments.text:
If the bushings comes out of the bushing holder, it means that you might have too much play between bushing and the bushing holder. Having a bushing holder that fit perfectly to the bushing means that it must be snug and not loose. The best to have the bushing holder that is snug enough but not too small is to "play with " the scaling of the objet in repetier (or other software you use) as Tech2c show us in one of his videos. I have tried to redesign the part in order to have the right dimension, but it seems that for type of part with fine walls, the behavior of the printed part in never what we usually can expect for most massive parts...
So try to scale down by 1% before, then see if you need more...

comments.text: I added an IR Z Probe 1.4 instead of the Inductive Proximity Sensor. Much easer to setup and plugs into the ramps z axis endstop with no mods. If you look in the made section I have a pic of it setup on a e3d v6.
comments.author: Terry50

comments.text: Would that work with a glass bed
comments.author: Terry50

comments.text: Yes it does work with a glass bed, i am using a 3mm glass plate on top of my aluminium bed, If your bed is raw aluminium you need to cover it with a black piece of paper or tape under the glass. This stops the IR reflecting off the raw aluminium surface. It's very easy to setup and needs no resisters or soldering at all, as it just plugs straight into the z axis endstop on your ramps board. It's very accurate and the repeatability is higher then inductive sensors.

comments.text: The steppers, end-stops, the 2004 LCD display, the cooling fan, the control board (I would recommend getting something a little better like perhaps a Rambo or duet wifi, but the one that comes with the kit should work fine), the power supply (although I would recommend buying one that supplies 12v, 36a and 360w, as the one that comes with the kit doesn't exactly look like the best quality) the pulleys (the printer should use gt2 pulleys, as that's pretty much the standard on most chinese kits) t8 8mm lead-screws, 8mm smooth hardened rods, possibly the bearings that drive the Y and X axis belts ride along (if they're the f623zz bearings, you should be good), the 5x8mm aluminum flex shaft coupler. I'm sure there's a couple things I'm missing but that should cover most of it.
comments.author: Nerwhal

comments.text: Thank you for taking the time to help me with this, I will look into getting a new board and power supply. I am not really sure if the bearings are f623zz bearings I will need to check and see. but everything else sounds like it could be used.
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text: You can of course use the power supply and ramps board that's listed in the BOM, or you can get something that's more expensive but also provides more features like a Rambo, Duet wifi etc. That's just personal preference, and isn't exactly required in order to get the machine running.

comments.text: The X gantry is probably skewed. When tightening the belts, tighten each belt so the gantry is perpendicular to the Y axis.

Any ideas? i LOOKED INTO MY FIRMWARE AND I HAD A Z OFFSET OF -1.8 sorry cap locks, i changed it to 1.8 since my probe sits higher than my nozzle.
comments.author: kd6hq

comments.text:
First send the new Z setting with M851
Then you have to send M500
Now send M501
It must be in this order.
First you send the new value (M851)
Then you save it to memory (M500)
Next your verify memory (M501)
If you send them out of sequence, then the setting gets erased before it's stored.

comments.text: Friend, if I increase the heated bed to 300 x 300 mm, do I need to change too the power supply to 24V or should I just plug in the 24V soldering of the table? Thank you.
comments.author: lhsistemas

comments.text: May I suggest:
comments.author: lhsistemas

comments.text: Its up to you. A 24v setup would heat faster, but is overkill for the motors, heater, etc. Most people with large heated beds opt to control their printer with an entirely different PSU, 12v, then get a separate 24v PSU specifically for their bed, and control it with a separate potentiometer (or just the one on the PSU)
comments.author: lhsistemas

comments.text: But will I have problems using only the 12V? I'm starting now, I'm curious and adventurous, and in Brazil some people do not like to help with information, they're very selfish. Thank you so much.

It would take a very long time to heat up, if it was even able to reach temperature at all. MAYBE if it was well insulated, AND the printer was enclosed, but without both of those done sufficiently, you should just use 12v on the rest of the printer and get a separate PSU+heated bed controller, 24v. It'll heat a lot faster, and will make it up to temperate. On 12v, it might not be powerful enough to reach ABS temperature.
comments.author: lhsistemas

comments.text: Z-Axis Problem:
comments.author: jinx

comments.text:
HI,
First :
what is the pitch of your lead screw.
For 2mm pitch 400 should be 1600
For 1,25 mm pitch 400 should be 2560
and with 1/16 polulu.
2) for your X and Y axis a move of 10 m and GT2 pulley 20TH means you have your stepper set to 1/2 instead of 1/16.
3) for your Z wiring try to wire your Z motor to the working X or Y axis and see if your motor move, if not try to modify your motor wiring, there is no reason your motor doesn't work.

comments.text: For anybody still on the hunt for 10mm anodized aluminium tubing, there may be a solution for your woes. I found this remix http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1949670 (credit to Chi Huang, aka CJ01) that uses 3/8th tubing (9.5250mm) instead. He also provided links to where you can actually obtain some of this tubing for a reasonable price (said links: anodized tubing https://www.mcmaster.com/#4568t12/=15pls2g, respective bearings to fit 3/8ths shaft https://www.mcmaster.com/#9368t22/=15g722l OR https://www.mcmaster.com/#1688k13/=15g763j). I Already purchased the anodized tubing and the ultra low friction oil embedded sleeve bearings. When I receive everything and begin the build process, Ill report my findings and whether it was a success or failure.
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text: For those in the US that are ordering these parts from McMaster-Carr, I just thought I'd throw in my two cents.  I ordered the rods that were listed by Okeasy above and they're fantastic.  I remodeled the parts these were used for just to be ultra sure that they would work (the remix ones had some wierd offset geometry errors when I loaded them).
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text: Glad to here that it worked out for you! I'm personally just lacking the space to build mine, hacksaw, miterbox, etc.. but needless to say, I'm desperate to build it.
comments.author: phorne_tca

comments.text: any updates you can give us (me)?
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text: I haven't been able to build my printer due to lack of space (amongst other things) but I can tell you that just doing a quick dry run on the 3/8th anodized tubing and the matching bearings, its absolutely smooth. It requires no lubrication as the bearings themselves are oil impregnated so as the bearing rides along the tube, you can actually feel some of the lubrication from the bearing on the tube. Since I haven't built my hypercube yet, I cant recommend it since I still don't have any real world results, however some individuals in the comments have decided to use it and I haven't seen any complaints yet. However, I would like to point out that the tubing is $10.84 and 6 of the ultra low friction oil imbedded sleeve bearings cost $8.34, which is altogether roughly $20, and they charged an additional $19.57 for shipping, so you'll be spending about $40 for it. Finally, credit goes to Chi Huang, aka CJ01 for 1. sourcing a good alternative to the 10mm anodized aluminum tubing as well as the matching bearings and 2. designing parts that would directly work with the 3/8th tubing. His design can be found here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1949670) should anybody else try it.
comments.author: makeshift_

comments.text:
Ok so I want to go from a build volume of 200 x 200 x 155 to 254 x 254 x 254, so to achieve that, are the values that I changed below correct? Any help is appreciated
4x 340mm (X) > 4x 394mm (x)
4x 303mm (Y) > 4x 357mm (y)
4x 350mm (Z) > 4x 454mm (z)
2x 285mm (Bed) > 2x 339mm (bed)
1x 135mm (Bed) > 1x 189mm (bed)
2x 8mm x 300mm Hardened steel smooth rod (y axis) > 2x 8mm x 354mm Hardened steel smooth rod (y axis)
2x 8mm x 340mm Hardened steel smooth rod (z axis) > 2x 8mm x 394mm Hardened steel smooth rod (z axis)
2x 10mm x 360mm anodized aluminium rod/tube (x axis) > 2x 10mm x 414mm anodized aluminium rod/tube (X axis)
1x T8 300mm Lead screw > 1x T8 354mm Lead screw
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text:
If you just added the difference between the old and new distance. Then you're fine.
However why such an odd value? specially on Z axis.
Don't forget that with a bigger bed, you're gonna have more sagging. That's why I'm building mine with dual Z motors, which requires more space in Y axis to achieve the same build volume.
comments.author: Okeasy

comments.text: Well the odd value for the z axis is purely just due to the fact that I want a build volume of 10inches cubed. Realistically speaking however, the chances of me using that much space are somewhat to none. But I figured that If I was going to increase the build volume on the x and y axis, might as well do it for the z. Also I forgot about the sagging that might occur. My current printer that I intend to gut and use for this one has 2 z motors so I should be fine, its just a matter of figuring out how much extra I need to add in the y axis to account for the extra z motor. Based off of the measurements I gave, how much more space should I add in the Y direction?

comments.text: This is the reason I didn't include nut-traps in all the parts, as M3 hex nuts outer dimensions can differ. The nuts I have are 5.5mm in diameter (measured between flat surfaces) but I also have M3 hex nuts that have a 6.5mm diameter.

I usually heat the nuts and use a pair of tweezers and a small screw screw driver to slide and adjust it inside. Make sure you do this carefully since taking the nut out would be very hard without damaging the part.

comments.text: Ok everyone....i am BEYOND frustrated with my printer. I cannot get it to print the first layer properly. I have leveled the bed until I am blue in the face, made a another bed that is 3/8" thick (as opposed to 1/8" thick that I originally had on there), tried mesh bed leveling, changed the offset in the firmware, reprinted and replaced cracked parts, used machinist parallels to make sure the XY carriage & rods are level with the bed, used a digital micrometer to adjust things .....and probably many other things that i cannot remember right now. The bed is 430mm x 430mm . Someone please help. I am certain that I am overlooking something very simple that will make me feel like a real idiot.. I can post my config.h file if needed. I have spent too much time and money on this printer to have to not work.  My company just spent $40k on another ABS 3D printer ( Stratasys Dimension bst1200) and I know the Hypercube can out print it. My HICTOP produced PLA prints that are on par with this big expensive printer. I want them to see what this printer can do
comments.author: mlbuxbaum

comments.text:
• The first thing I would check is the firmware offset of the print head. I don't know what version of Marlin you are using but I use 1.1.0-RC7. I use the M501 command to check the offset and then the M851 command if it needs to be adjusted. Check the offset I suspect that it may be a negative number perhaps something like Z = -0.3 as an example. If it is a negative number try setting it to Z = 0.0, save it to memory (M500) and then try printing a test piece. It should print where you have the nozzle set. So it will print in the "air" instead of on the bed. Then you can slowly bring the nozzle down to a proper height using the firmware offset commands.

  • How flat is your bed? Most aluminum sheets are not flat. They have little hills and valleys in them. The only way that I know of to have a perfectly flat aluminum bed is to have the bed milled flat. Using something longer than the bed, like a steel ruler or anything that has a straight edge on it, place it on the surface of the bed. On the opposite side from you place a bright light. Slowly move the ruler across the bed you should not see any light between the surface of the bed and the ruler. If you do your bed is not flat. If you do not want to have the bed milled (it can be expensive) you could try sanding it yourself.
comments.author: mlbuxbaum

comments.text: I will do your step 1 as soon as I get the new parts Tech2C has come up with for the XY Joiner and X carriage printer and installed. The bed is pretty flat. My first bed was 1/8" thick and sagged in the middle due to the weight of the heater pad and the distance between support points. I would lay a steel rule across the 1/8" bed and I could see under the center of the rule on the bed.I had our machine shop cut me a 3/8" bed and it is flat. No gap in the center of the rule anymore. Either left to right or front to back. But I could have the machine shop mill this one is I still find issues.
comments.author: kd6hq

comments.text: First thing: Get rid of those goofy washers they send with the sensor. That's the first thing I ditched. You don't need them for our application. The nuts alone give a flatter surface to the mounting ring. Second thing, the light must light up when triggered. That's how you know its working. The resistor divider needs to be across ground and the signal wire so that it only drops the output signal to around 5V. Make sure its not putting out over 5 volts. I set mine to 3.8 volts and it works fine. My wires were not labeled but turned out to be: Brown+, Blue-, Black signal.

If you used resistors to bring the probe's voltage down to 5v, the led most likely wont turn on. I used a 1N4007 diode instead. There was a very informative comment about this on Thomas Sanladerer video about auto leveling.

comments.text:
Hi, after building my Hypercube and getting all the homing commands to work correctly, it was time to clean up the wiring.
I used the spiral wrap and tucked it and the motor cables into the groove in the aluminum extrusion. At this point I was ecstatic.
I then tried the homing commands again and I got the very same problem you have described on my Z axis only.
After a lot of head scratching I thought to change the Z axis motor cable with the new spare motor cable. I got the same problem.
I then checked the continuity of each wire in each cable I was using for the Z axis. There was a bad wire in each cable. These were both never used cables and never abused or kinked in any way. I was able to replace the one bad wire in the motor cable bundle and I have been printing every day now for a week. This printer design is the best I have seen so far.
I give Tech2c so much praise for all his thorough and hard work. You can bet any cable assemblies I get in the future will be
checked for continuity. Maybe this will fix your problem. (If interested I bought my stepper motors from Banggood)
comments.author: Nightreve

The "bowden mount" ist to attach an bowden extruder, like this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767951

Did a large print overnight to see how it would print ( i knew of a few issues already) and discovered a few more issues.
ONE-The aluminum rods I am using are not, in fact, anodized. I will be contacting the seller today. They are 'dusting' already.
TWO-Both bearings on the top bearing holder of the XY carraige came out of their holder and were just sitting on the rod.
THREE- the 10mm aluminum rods sag too much over the 560mm length of the bed. So I ordered https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0050RMC7W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
to help alleviate this issue. My prints were showing ringing or oscillating on the x movement prints, but the Y movement prints were very nice and smooth.
FOUR - I am also seeing a vibration on the Z movements at intervals around every 5mm of movement. If i just run the build plate down using S3D, at regular intervals you can hear a vibration. I will have to look into that to see if something in the motors or guide rails is misaligned.
FOUR - my build plate sags (sagged) in the middle. Due to several factors I think. The plate is only 3.25mm thick(1/8"), it spans 430mm and has the weight of the heat pad underneath in the center. I fixed that issue by using a center rail under the build platform with an adjustment screw on the front and back of the plate to push the center area back up into alignment.
comments.author: mlbuxbaum
