comments.text: I'm working on modifying the build to use 3/8" Aluminum rod/tube and Igus bearings printed in PETG since we can't seem to figure out the metric system over on this side of the pond... sheesh. For those that may not know, Igus actually sells their Drylin material in 1.75 and 2.85mm filament rolls so you can print your own bearings and have been kind enough to release the .stl files to go along right on their site. They also have some graphs that show friction coefficients for various plastics which is also helpful. PET-P is not too far above the Drylin material and PET-P is not a whole lot different from PET-G concerning friction coefficients. I have done hours and hours of research on this and there just isn't an easy way to get 10mm anodized tube here in the US. I have contacted many companies who can provide it but they either don't sell to peons like me or have a minimum order of 36 pieces such as the case of K&S manufacturing. 3/8" Aluminum rod is actually 9.5mm which is not far off from the 10mm we need so adjustments to plastic parts should not be too drastic. 3/8" Aluminum rod can be had at the local hardware stores cheap as chips. Its not anodized but by printing the Igus bearings in PETG I'm thinking wear should not be as drastic as steel/bronze bushings would be as in the original plans. One last thing, if you are even remotely considering building one of these please head over to the Google+ page Jinx created so we can share and contribute in one place. If we all put our heads together we can take this great thing Tech2C started and make it even more awesome. https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/104542201288100910747
comments.author: mister_nobody

comments.text: I was actually looking at 3/8 OD rods. I found this. https://www.mcmaster.com/#anodized-aluminum/=15adzc3 It's anodize aluminum. The only problem is it's sold in 6 foot section. comments.text: So after much research, I believe 4140 Cold Finished, Heat Treated alloy is the next best option to anodized aluminum. Everything about it is better besides the fact the it weighs more than aluminum but is still a little less than steel (or the average 10mm shafts). It has a lower surface friction than anodized aluminum, while having a harder surface and tensile strength. Best part too, its cheaper than any other anodized aluminum Ive found. Waiting to hear back from supplier on the aluminum. I'll post link if the price is right. Besides that, if anyone else is looking for alternative to aluminum this is it.

comments.text: Hi there guys. I'm building this awesome printer a d I've reached a point where I don't know what else to do. I'm having real issues aligning the X and Y system. All good as far as X axis but when I try to align the Y axis, it just doesn't get straight and it doesn't slide well. Is it the fact that I made it bigger in order to have a 350 mm travel area? Is this system limited to the original size or should I look into something else?
comments.author: jmlcatarino

comments.text: I too had problems with smooth travel of the Y-axis. Moving the X carriage in the Y direction on either side of the X-axis would cause a slight deflection of the single bearing XY joiner and cause the Y-axis to bind. It was not due to an alignment of the problem with the Y-axis rods. I replaced the single bearing XY joiner with the dual bearing XY joiner remix by jinx and presto the binding disappeared. The dual bearing eliminated the flex at the XY joiner and now the X carriage movement is very smooth in all directions of travel.
comments.author: jmlcatarino

comments.text: I had a similar problem with mine!! Ensure the idlers at the back are butted up real tight to the pot of the frame!

comments.author: mlbuxbaum

comments.text: I ran into the same issue it tuned out to be the polyfuse on the RAMPS 1.4 board tripping which would cause the Marlin firmware to activate the safety feature and shut down both the bed and the extruder heaters. The root cause was my heated bed was drawing more current (almost 16 amps in this case) than the MOSFET on the RAMPS could handle. I resolved the issue by using an external MOSFET heated bed controller, https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HCVJ3K2.
comments.author: mlbuxbaum

Not sure if anyone has already mentioned, IGUS make a replacement for the bronze bearing - JSM-1012-10 (10mm ID - 12mm OD), these are only 10mm long though (I bought these through RS components). I managed to fit 2 in each bearing holder, one at each end, and it seems to work OK. Hopefully this should help the aluminium shafts last longer. I'll also be using IGUS RJ4JP-01-08 bearings for all the others, this should make the unit run very quietly.
I'm using aluminium shafts from Wickes (here in the UK), they work very well. I had the same issue of play in the bearings as TECH2C had in the video, but his solution worked to eradicate that.

comments.text: Right, I have built the printer and its printing!! yay! But the Z axis isn't calibrating properly! I'm using the same leadscrew as in the build but I can't get the steps per mm right! I have used prusa calculator but no joy! I'm using 1/32 steps and I believe its a 2mm pitch! my steps are 3200 per mm but it is making to big of gaps between layers!! please help! thanks, guys!
comments.author: DrDenzil

comments.text: http://prusaprinters.org/calculator/
comments.author: DrDenzil

comments.text:
When calibrating XYZE I usually do this steps:
1) set for example 400 steps/mm, home Z. ( 2400 steps/mm is your 's' variable)
2) rise Z to 100mm ( 100mm is your 'a' variable )
3) measure height by your caliper - oh it just 25.6mm!! ( 25.6mm is your 'b' variable )
4) calculate new steps per mm - a / b * s = 100 / 25.6 * 400 = 1562.5
5) repeat one more time if needed
...
PROFIT!
comments.author: DrDenzil

comments.text: Ok ill have to gibe these a try and see what happens!!
comments.author: sviatoy

comments.text: Had a similar problem. The lead screw specs said it was a 2mm pitch and it was really an 8mm. So set it to 400 steps per mm and it tracks perfectly now.

comments.text:
Further to the nema motor with the bent shaft,I have been offered a partial refund,which i have accepted.I removed the old lead screw today,and to my surprise,the magnets came off the screw with only moderate hand pressure!I also found the screw has only a single lead,whereas the one i'm replacing it with is a 4 lead screw.
So if you have ordered your lead screw equipped nema motor from banggood or any other chinese supplier,you might be advised to take it apart and check the security of the magnets on the lead screw,as well as checking for bends in the screw.
Back to printing parts.

Are you using S3D? I had the same issue a while back. Where S3D would add a random solid infill layer on some models.
The work around was to change the layer height slightly, ie from 0.2000 to 0.2001 or 0.3000 to 0.3001.
I believe they have fixed this now, but it may still work if you are using a different slicer.

Just Google Ch340g.

comments.text: Just a note for anyone needing to cut bearing rods. They are very hard to cut with a hacksaw if not impossible. I did cut a couple but it ruined my hacksaw blade. I then switched to an angle grinder with a thin cut off disk. The cut off tool works great and leaves a clean finish. A little bit of filing will make it perfect.

comments.text:
No support required. Turn on your cooling fan from 9mm height, 70% speed is enough (PETG).
When printing the fan duct I've noticed Cura 15.04 doesn't recognise the top of the duct as a bridge and just prints diagonally like normal. Therefore rotate the fan duct 45 degrees anti-clockwise to ensure the first top layer is shortest path between the bridge.

comments.author: Tech2C

comments.text:
The outer diameter of those bushings are 1/2 inch = 12.7mm. The dual bushing holder is for 12mm outer diameter. As fastslash25 said you'd need to cut out a cylinder to make them fit.
The XY joiner you could reverse the process and add to the holes an extra 0.5mm to ensure they are centered when clamped.
comments.author: OmegaWolf3d

comments.text: If they don't work you could always edit the Stl. just boolean union a cylinder into it and take a cut out.

comments.text: it might be already too late to add this comment but i think the Z-motor should rest on the bottom of the printer, simply because, with this design, the coupler will be always in tension and it'll act just like a spring.....for example, if you might bump the printer (or maybe even the vibrations of the printer itself) the whole axis would move, again, like a spirng, thus affecting the layers...not much, since there are 2 rails and the coupler if more rigid than a proper spring, but still...

As you might have noticed (3D printed) Pokémon started appearing on the streets. If you want to catch (print) them all, PokéMarvin is the best companion for you! :)

This little guy is just circa 30mm tall, so it makes a nice keychain or backpack zipper pull combining the symbols of 3D printing and the love for Pokémon.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Resolution:

0,15

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This model is a bit tricky due to the tight tolerances. It can be nicly printed on a well leveled Ultimaker without any supports. Print all parts as orinented and print them slowly! I used 20 mm/s wall speed for most parts and 10 mm/s for the knob. Also print two of the knob piece at the same time to let each layer cool down before the next is deposited. 190 celsius seems to be just right.
If printed correctly, all parts should snap together, but if you use it as a keychain or zipper pull maybe you should glue them together.

title: A burgeoning capsule Planter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A burgeoning capsule Planter
(monochrome version)

A beautiful flower pot permeated with a organic double wall voronoi outside shell. This wonderful art decor is also ideal as a gift and as decoration everywhere an eye-catcher!

There are two version available. One with a small an one with a larger pot.

Color version: monochrome (One-part object: The pot is fixedly attached to the outer voronoi-shell.)

Pot version: small and large

Original size: 11.7 x 8.7 x 11.3 cm (can be scaled)

About the Photos: Own 3D-print of the 2-color version* with Wood (outside) and brown PLA (pot). The wood outside was not cleaned, so that remains a rough natural look. You can print it more precise like the rendering images.

* Here is the two-color (two parts) version available: https://pinshape.com/items/25606-3d-printed-a-burgeoning-capsule-planter-2-colorpart-version

If you have no 3D-printer, you can buy a printed copy here:
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/designgravity

Rafts:

Yes

Notes:

I have printed it with 5 layers and the pot was waterproof. I used 1-1,5 cm raft for a good stand during the printing process. Printed without support.

Notes:

Test before planting, if the pot/vase is waterproof. Depending on the material and printing, the pot may not be waterproof. In this case, the pot can inside coated with a suitable lacquer. Or simple glue a pvc-foil in.

title: Clip for Flat-Fold Flippin' Phone Stand

description.text:
This is a simple and quick to print clip which holds alvinhochun's 'Flat-fold Flippin' Phone Stand' (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608339) together when in transit.

I absolutely love the stand and think it's the best folding phone stand on here, but I've found that when just stored in a bag or a pocket, the stand can unfold itself and the main lever part often falls off.

This clip holds the whole stand together so it cant un-fold on it's own and also holds the main flipper in place so it can't fall off.

It simply slides over the side and locks into place in the gap where the feet flips are.

tl;dr - I upgraded the heatsink on my Mk7...
I was having problems printing with the Safety Orange ABS using my T-o-M/Mk7.
By the time I got the toolhead up to the temperature I needed to extrude reliably on the hot end (225C) the cold end was getting too hot and the feed wheel was chewing into the filament stopping the extrusion half way through a print. 
I tried upgrading the fan, and the z-axis but without effect. Plain ABS and Red/Blue both worked but I can extrude them at much lower temperatures. 
Luckily I had some left over 2mm copper plate that I used to make the HBP.
So far, so good.
Made a sketch in OpenScad because things have to have a file that isn't an image... Perhaps it will be useful if someone makes this on a cnc.

Cut a rectangular section of copper plate 6cm x 5cm (to leave a border of 1cm on the sides and top.) I used a dremmel, remember to use oil or cutting fluid when cutting or drilling copper or Aluminium. 
Center the Mk7 heatsink on the plate with the holes closest to one of the long edges. Mark the position of the bolt holes and drill 3mm holes. 
Attach the heatsink to the copper plate using m3 bolts and drill out the hole for the stepper shaft with a 7mm drill using the heatsink as a template.
Cut some fins around the sides and top, grind out and rough edges and optionally polish/sand.
The nylon spacers will now be too long so shorten them by an appropriate amount and the reassemble the fan assembly fan->heatsink->copper plate->spacers and reassemble the extruder.

comments.text: Hi guys, sorry for the late reply. It's difficult to know without knowing the particular relay board and wiring setup, including which pin on the nodemcu you've used. TTL should have a threshold of about 2.7V for a HIGH signal and ~0.4V for LOW, so I don't think a 3.3V or 5V supply should (-should-) alter its behavior. The on-board logic probably uses [VCC] as a reference though, so if your INPUT is lower than VCC when active, maybe that will have unforeseen consequences?

description.text:
This is my first design and frankly my first serious print, that's why it isn't perfect.

What do you need:

  • 3x cap
  • 3x dowel_short
  • 1x base_bottom and base_top
  • 1x stablilizer (for each level, it goes between pillars)
  • 3x pillars for each level (pillar height 15.5cm/6.1in)
  • 3x dowel_long (for each level, and exta 3 to mount base)
  • glue (if you printing in abs something like UHU might be perfect choise)

Important - dowel_long might need scaling up or down, depending from material you printing in. Print just one or two and check if they fit.

How to assembly:

  • 3x glue dowel_long to base_bottom
  • 3x glue pillar
  • glue stabilizer
  • 3x glue pillar
  • repeat until required height is reached
  • 3x glue dowel_long
  • glue base_top
  • 3x glue dowel_short
  • 3x glue cap

Printing tip:
As I mentioned this was one of first prints so I make couple mistakes, one of which was wall thickness. I printed it in 0.8 which is not enough. Maybe 3 or 2 would be sufficient enough.

RepRap

comments.text:
There is a problem when slicing 2, p1-2, H1, and WLL2 using Simplify3D. This may also happen with others slicers.
Each one of these is the union of two shapes, but the portion of one shape inside the other shape (the intersection) has not been removed.
So the pieces are not manifold.
Due to a bug in Simplify3D, a gap will be created between the two shapes and the piece falls apart.
The workaround is to select each piece and apply Mesh / Separate Connected Surfaces.
I also had to use supports in my Qidi Tech printer.
Smooth sailing after that.

title: Fully Customisable and Modular Lightsaber
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Please check the print settings section, it is important to ensure the Lightsabers components are printed correctly.

This is my original, modular and fully customisable Lightsaber!

You can see the cover video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ltv0F1Etztc

The basic saber is comprised of 4 components, these being the hilt top half, hilt bottom half, button and a blade guard. This gives you a standard saber; you can add more components to customise it however you like! You can use the double ended adapter to make a Darth Maul style double ended saber.

All of the components can be printed without support material; the pieces pressure fit together and so over time may come too loose; however through assembling and disassembling these sabers over and over throughout a two day period the pieces have never come too loose to fall apart on their own.

Please check out my YouTube channel and Instagram for more: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWRyzFmzOnutHKeKtiF-8qw

https://www.instagram.com/sodacanhobbyman/ (@SodaCanHobbyman)

04/09/16 -

As you may have noticed, there are only 6 models that you can download to create your saber, I have decided to upload this thing as a 'Work in Progress' just so you guys know that I will be adding more and more files for added customisation in the near future! I have plans for new blade guards, new hilt top and bottom halves, new buttons and even more customisation options to make the saber truly your own.

I have noted that some of the pressure fit pieces are rather tight, so please take care when assembling and disassembling the saber as you may break the connectors (which I have done a few times myself).

I am always open to suggestions on what to add and how to improve the parts that already exist :)

Printer:

Creality CR7

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm (200 Microns)

Infill:

15%

Notes:

IMPORTANT: The model pictured is scaled down to 0.75x normal scale in the slicer, this is to ensure that it is of optimal size for smaller printers as well as a good general size to be of similar scale to the lightsabers in the movies. For me personally, I think the sabers look best at this scale; however you can print at normal scale if you want but please be aware that they may be slightly larger than is realistic and/or optimal.

Please ensure that you print "Hilt Top Half 1" upside down (the opposite to the default) as the overhang will be smaller and therefore will not require supports.

I recommend printing with at least 3 perimeter walls, or 1.2mm thick walls (with a 0.4mm nozzle) to ensure the most amount of strength, especially to ensure that the connections are strong enough not to snap during assembly and disassembly. The infill at 15% helps to save time, but as these pieces are not load bearing the infill does not really need to be much higher.

Supports are definitely unnecessary for all the pieces, however if you scale the pieces up at all it may be worth considering them as the overhangs may then be too large to print without supports.

Feel free to sand or paint the saber afterwards;

I'd love to see some well painted/finished lightsabers, however I may be too lazy to do this with my own.
I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to design all the components of the Lightsaber.

author: PDUCLOZ

description.text:
Water sensor to measure the level of water in a tank. It is based on the changing capacity of the capacitator that is submerged in water. the capacitator is composed from two concentric coils made from enameled copper wire. (To measure the capacity I used the QTouch system described at Atmel http://www.atmel.com/images/doc8207.pdf)
The obvious way to build something like this would be to use two concentric pipes that are isolated with paint. But it's tricky to ensure that the pipes are longterm isolated due to imperfections of the coating.

comments.text: Csn you go into greater detail about the software you use.....is it possible to use this with an arduino
comments.author: superman

comments.text: I guess so since I used a mega32 for my tests and the arduino is based on a similar type. For the measurements there are a lot of ways I chose the qtouch system which simply requires 2 io ports / resistor and capacitator see http://www.atmel.com/images/doc8207.pdfhttp://www.atmel.com/images/do... for deatils about it.

I really like @muckychris' design. It is one of the first things I print with any new filament I get, even samples. Instead of making labels I wrote on them with a fine point Sharpie marker. Well, that didn't look so hot. So, I decided to replicate his design and instead add raised text on the lower shelf for the type of material it is. Per the original design, the reason for the dual height was so you can see what 1mm and 2mm looks like (important especially with translucent filaments), and now it facilitates adding the letters. There are blanks remaining faithful to the original design.

I've also made slightly longer Filament Type ID chip to separate the material types (ie, ABS, PLA, HIPS, etc)

I've made smaller chips for each of the different filament types I have. If you like this and there's an ID or filament chip you'd like that is missing, let me know and I'll do my best to add it.

Please follow me on Twitter

remixed_from.author: dude9001
remixed_from.title: Spool holder with a longer shaft

description.text:
04/03/2017
Added a longer 40mm mount to give me clearance on my FT 2020 I3.

10/22/2016
Updated back lash arm for clearance issues that I was having with arm 2. Made the arm with a 3mm nut slot to lock the arm in place.

10/20/2016
Update to spool holder.
I was having issues when running full rolls on my FT-5 the filament would come off the spool with large fast movements. I added a few updates to help with this issue. I call it a back lash arm.

I wanted a spool holder that was quick and easy to change the spool. It also needed to be compact. I wanted to mount multiple rolls on my FT Kossel 2020 and my FT-5. I came across just the thingy I needed ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1468552 ) and made a few changes to it and several additions. Instead of mounting it horizontally I went vertical to save room. The roll balances on the mount and is actually very stable. There are small friction surfaces on it to help keep the roll from unwinding. You can put it on the end of 2020 channel or the optional straight and corner mounts. I added a optional filament guide.

Parts list:

1 - 608Z bearing
2 - 5mm thread x 10mm long cap screws for corner and straight mounts
2 - 5mm channel nuts for 2020

Printer:

Folgertech Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Snap these hooks onto waterpipes above the wall fastener.
Scale the models to fit your pipe size in the slicer program. The files are ø35 mm (ø1.38").
File L1 has one hook.
File L3 has three hooks.

title: Phantom 3 or 4 LG Stylo 2 Controller Mount

description.text: I recently purchased a new LG Stylo 2 which has a great screen and plenty of processing power, perfect for use on my Phantom. Unfortunately, after putting on a protective case it wouldn't fit in the device holder on the controller. Also, the phone is something of an odd size so finding a sun shade to fit was a bit of a challenge as well. I decided to get out my 3D printer and make a solution to both.

Designed on Solidworks 2014

title: Sugar packet holder with tight closure

description.text: Good for keeping packets of Splenda, Sweet-n-Low, etc. (or even actual sugar) in your desk at work, or while travelling. The lid slides in and holds firmly enough that it won't likely work loose, but has a thumb-pull for easy removal. Or just don't bother to print the lid and use only the base if you want to leave it out on the counter (or just print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20170 instead since it's prettier). 2014-05-22: Slight modification, made it a little taller as I was finding the generic packets are just a bit taller and it was kind of snug even with the regular packet.s

comments.text: I actually have to take a medicine 2x daily that I have to mix with generic Splenda packages.  Thanks for this design!

description.text: I hate leaving my headphones laying on the desk, but I couldn't find a good sized-hook or mount for them. This is sized to slide onto a 1-inch thick surface, and hold headphones beneath the desk (especially if you put a little anti-slip putty on the side that sticks on the top of the desk. It will print on a Thing-o-Matic, but's probably too big for a Cupcake.
I found that increasing fill helped make this a little more rigid, but it worked fine with default settings on a Thing-o-Matic using Replicator G 25.
This model was ripped from the Ark Survival Evolved dev kit, and not designed to be 3Dprinted. PVA supports are your friend.

title: Box Mod bottom feeder mechanical with push button lock

description.text:
External size are 82x44x24.

Simple to print and to mount.
U need:

  • some battery contact, i used keystone 5209 > http://fave.co/2bsgxvX
  • brass or copper or silver strip, i used KS 0,81x12,6 > http://fave.co/2cf8csE

This is a simple sensor to measure the moisture in soil. I made it for a small plant watering project. The moisture is measured by the changing capacity of the two concentric coils which are made out of enameled copper wire. In addition there are two unisolated wires made out of stainless steal to measure the ohmic value of the soil to measure the change of minerals in the soil.
The whole sensor is then casted into cement to ensure a homogenic filling of the coils and to prevent roots from growing into the capacitor field, which would interfere with the measurement.
In the last picture u can see a step answer of the sensor when it was try and droped in water. Since this is the raw value of the qTouch (http://www.atmel.com/images/doc8207.pdf) measurement its hard to tell what real capacity lies behind this (x axes is in seconds).

comments.text: Are the stainless steel wires in contact with the soil? Do they protrude out of the concrete casing? Since the capacitive coils are embedded in the concrete, are they actually measuring the moisture of the concrete, and that tracks the moisture content of the soil?
comments.author: mattmoses

comments.text: the ss wires are very close to the surface < 1mm so the idea is that salts and things like it change the ohmic resistance. The coils measure the moisture of the concrete. But I think thats fine too, in professional measurements they use a similar system where wires are embedded in concrete.
comments.author: mattmoses

comments.text: What range of values have you been able to detect and what moisture levels do they correspond to?
comments.author: rubisco2000

comments.text: In the last picture u can see a step answer of the sensor when it was try and droped in water. Since this is the raw value of the qTouch measurement its hard to tell what real capacity lies behind this. After my holidays I will take a closer look at it

description.text:
I tried using Meshmixer to remove the cut lines for the waffle and make it look more like an Eggo waffle. Those who are fans of Stranger Things will understand why :-)
This is definitely a work in progress since I've never tried something like this in Meshmixer before but it's a good first start.
The model is still the same scale as the original but along with the cut lines removed I added a hole for in case someone wanted to scale it down to something like a charm or keychain. I would suggest keychain since charm size is pushing the limits of how small my printer can print successfully.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30% or 100%

Notes:

I printed in Hatchbox silver filament as a test for something like a charm or keychain. I scaled it down to about 15% which wasn't the best print but about the size of a larger charm.
I used Acrylic paint and experimented with it until I found a color I liked. I'm going to give it a day or two and see if I still like the color for the final unpainted model.

Update

I shrank the model down and resized the keychain hole. I also smoothed out the model which took care of most of the unwanted lines from where I modified the original. I also cranked it up to 100% infill which will make it more durable. The new file is called Waffle_Keychain and likely is about as far as I'm going with this remix.
At least until I get some new equipment to try my next idea :)

description.text:
Something got into my laptop fan and broke off all the blades but one. Needless to say, cooling was less than perfect after that.

This thing is designed to go over the top of a fan's bladeless hub and thus provide new fan blades.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You'll definitely have to adjust the .scad file to suit your fan's dimensions and rotation.

Flip this design upside-down and print with supports.

After printing, cut off any existing blades on the old fan and glue on with CA ("super") glue or hot glue.

(HINT: if the size is a little too tight, hot glue can help soften the plastic and get it to fit.)

CAUTION

Plastic may soften and deform if used in too hot an area.

comments.author: DC010

description.text: This lesson is an introduction to 3D shapes and creating music using the structure of a 3D build.
CCSS

Students will be selecting a 3D shape to print and pausing the print to add beads to create a musical instrument. Standards CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.G.A.3
Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, "flat") or three-dimensional ("solid"). CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.G.B.4
Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/"corners") and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).

Creating with Morphi App Using the iPad app Morphi, students will select a shape that they want to create from the shape choices. Show the ruler tool and have them select inches so that it is sized to 2 inches. Show them how the slider works when you click on the shape to increase the size of your shape. Exporting the Design Students will need to export the design for 3D printing from Morphi as an .stl file and share it with the teacher for final printing. Printing will take approximately 1 hour - 1.5 hours depending on the piece.
Rafts: yes
Supports: depends on the shape (sphere - supports are suggested)
Resolution: 0.2 mm
Infill: 10% Printing the Design As the honeycomb interior is built, you will pause the design about half way through to add beads. After adding the beads, you will resume the build.

• Clear Filament is ideal to see the beads
  • Seed Beads

• MATH.CONTENT.K.G.A.3
  • MATH.CONTENT.K.G.B.4
1 Day

description.text:
I was really fascinated by Azetec death whistles, and decided to reverse engineer one, by using cross section images on Google, and explanatory videos on YouTube.

The angle and strength that you blow with into the whistle affects the sound (subtly).

This is one of the better sounding ones after quite a fair bit of trial-and-error. What do you think?

https://youtu.be/NcdXHN-ka_o

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Shell thickness: 0.39mm (or less)

You can scale it up to decrease the fundamental frequency, but it will require more effort to blow.

Snip off any stringing (if any) especially around the whistle holes. They make the sound duller.

The whistle can get really loud! Remember to protect your hearing and play with it responsibly.

I noticed a lack of ping pong paddles on Thingiverse, so I decided to fill the gap.  I call her "Striped Freedom," even though she looks like a French flag.  This has been tested in the heat of battle, and works great as a paddle.  Even if you lose your match, the nerd factor of this is so high, your opponent will be too busy gawking to gloat.
This was printed on the high seting with 4 shells and a 20% infill, which gives it a pretty good weight.

This is a multitool keychain I made on Fusion 360. I haven't measured the hex sizes, so you`ll have to measure them if you plan on using the wrenches. If you end up making it, please comment a link to it so I can use it for the picture. You will get a shout out.

A quite simple LED spot lamp.

Notes to the design:
The taps can, when printed at some printers (at least mine), break off, but the shade fits quite firmly to the holder, and this will normally be enough to hold it, otherwise glue will do the trick.

Preparing the print:
spotBoejle.stl should be X axis rotated 270 deg
spotBaseTop.stl should be X axis rotated 180 deg
to print without support.
The rest should print as they are without support.

Hide and connect the wires in the base cover.
The socket used is from here: http://www.bjb.com/index.php?productid=242025 but other models will probably fit as well.

Update 2016-09-22: An updated version without taps added and a base version for 3 spots added. Note that the holes along the side at the picture are not present in the design file. Cover for the unused holes is added too.
Designed using FreeCAD
